_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Executive Summary for MidAmerican Energy CompanyA?s Greater Des Moines Energy Center Risk Management Plan 



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies (40 CFR 68.155(a))



MidAmerican Energy Company's (MidAmerican) Greater Des Moines Energy Center is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. The commitment is demonstrated by an accidental release program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with processes at the facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent potential releases of regulated substances.



The Facility and Regulated Processes (40 CFR 68.155(b))



MidAmerican Energy Company's primary activity is the generation of electrical energy by combustion of natural gas in a combined-cycle, combustion turbine facility. 

Part of that activity involves the use of a system that provides aqueous ammonia for selective catalytic reduction in the heat recovery steam generators. The aqueous ammonia storage and forwarding system (the process) consists of a storage tank, two forwarding pumps, associated piping, valves, and instrumentation.  Vaporized ammonia is injected into the SCR section. The flue gas entrains the ammonia and as the mixture passes through the SCR, it undergoes a reaction that reduces nitrogen oxides to meet the standrds within the facility's air permit.



The maximum inventory of aqueous ammonia in the process is 25,000 gallons (187,220 pounds). Ammonia in the storage tank is concentrated at 29.4% in water. 



Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios (40 CFR 68.165(a)(1))



To perform the required off-site consequence analysis for the facility, MidAmerican used the EPA's Risk Management Program RMP*Comp, Version 1.07. The worst-case scenario involved the catastrophic release of aqueous ammonia from the storage tank. In this scenario, all 25,000 gallons of aqueous ammonia is relea

emergency response policies at the stationary source; 

       (b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled; 

       (c) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; 

       (d) The five-year accident history; 

       (e) The emergency response program; and 

       (f) Planned changes to improve safety. 



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 



The facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 for Program Level 1 processes. The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with appropriate engineering and nationally recognized design standards. The following sections describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place. 



Emergency Response Plan 



The Greater Des Moines Energy Center employees will not respond to accidental releases of regulated substances; therefore, the requirements of A?68.95 are not applicable to the Greater Des Moines Energy Center.  The Greater Des Moines Energy Center has coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee to be included in their emergency response plan.  The Greater Des Moines Energy Center has also coordinated with the local fire department to be included in their fire mitigation plan.



The Polk County Emergency Services and Disaster Agency is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which emergency response has been coordinated. 



The telephone number of the LEPC Coordinator is (515) 283-4768.

 

Five-Year Accident History 



There have been no accidents at the Greater Des Moines Energy Center. 



The Emergency Response Program



Ammonia monitors have been installed around the aqueous ammonia storage tank at the Greater Des Moines Energy Center.  In the event of an ammonia release, plant operators will receive an alarm from the monitors.  The plant operators will then noti

fy emergency response personnel to an ammonia release at the Greater Des Moines Energy Center.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



No changes to this plan are anticipated at this time.
